creditline: Gift of funds from the Print and Drawing Curatorial Council
description: Black charcoal drawing of a figure with cat ears, dressed in a long draping gown that falls to the floor and gathers around her feet.
provenance: The artist, 1999-2010; [Flowers Gallery, London & New York] sold to MIA, 2010.
text: An accomplished sculptor and draftsman, Nicola Hicks's work combines sharply observed studies of animals and people with an imaginative element of fantasy. She creates strange, evocative new beasts that seem to live and breathe both on the page and in three dimensions. Her monumental Cat Woman is a self-portrait, where the artist convincingly portrays herself as part feline, part human. With charcoal, Hicks works and reworks areas of the face and body with intensity, particularly around the eyes, giving the figure a dark, shadowy presence and haunting psychological depth. The figure's hybrid appearance and regal character are reminiscent of the enduringly powerful ancient Egyptian goddesses dwelling in the galleries of the British Museum, especially Sekhmet, the lioness-headed warrior goddess.
title: Cat Woman
